G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3.

*Davis v. Comerford*, 483 Mass. 164, 166.proposition: Venue is proper in Chelsea District Court because the property at issue is located in Chelsea and the acts complained of occurred within this jurisdiction.

Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186,.proposition: Plaintiff Jessica Harris (“Plaintiff”) brings this action against her landlord, Mark Thompson (“Defendant”), for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186, section 14.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises is liable for damages or, where appropriate, rent abatement and other statutory relief.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to peaceful and habitable possession, free from substantial interference caused by the landlord or the landlord’s failure to act.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion does not give a one-sentence definition of the covenant, but it applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 in a way that presupposes quiet enjoyment protects tenants against substantial interference with their tenancy where the landlord, with notice or reason to know of a hazardous condition, fails to act reasonably. The court characterizes prior § 14 cases as involving a landlord’s failure to repair known defects rendering premises uninhabitable, and it reaffirms that negligent failures to correct such conditions can violate the statutory covenant, which aligns with the proposition’s focus on peaceful and habitable possession free from substantial landlord-caused interference or inaction.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear … to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to peaceful and habitable possession, free from substantial interference caused by the landlord or the landlord’s failure to act.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that it is breached where tenants are “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment by conditions that render the premises not “reasonably habitable,” even if the landlord did not intend the interference, so long as it was the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted. The court applies this to late-night noise from a lounge the landlord leased and controlled, emphasizing substantial interference with peaceful and habitable possession caused by the landlord’s conduct or failure to act. This aligns closely with the stated proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain secure common areas constitutes a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The case does address interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the interference found here arose from the landlord’s failure to maintain the *tenant’s apartment* in sanitary, watertight condition, particularly a porous wall causing sewage flooding, not from failure to maintain secure or safe *common areas*. The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis repeatedly links liability to unsanitary conditions and flooding in Solomon’s own unit, and there is no discussion of common-area security. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about secure common areas.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.” (385 Mass. at 104)

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain secure common areas constitutes a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that loss of use of common areas due to criminal activity can constitute a serious interference with quiet enjoyment, but it does not ground that interference in a duty to "maintain secure common areas" in the sense of providing security services or general crime prevention. The court expressly rejects any requirement that the landlord provide specific security measures or around‑the‑clock security, and instead frames liability under the quiet enjoyment covenant in terms of the landlord’s failure to take any reasonable measures to remove unlawful actors it can control. Thus the proposition, as phrased, overstates what the decision holds.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… There is no authority, however, for the proposition that the defendant must provide around the clock security or other police services. … We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Lipsitz v. Smith*, 236 Mass. 72, 74 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes on lessors a duty to maintain common areas in a condition that does not endanger tenants’ safety.
*Lipsitz v. Smith*, 236 Mass. 72, 74 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns construction of a testamentary trust and determination of who takes the remainder interest; it does not involve landlord–tenant relationships, lessors, or duties to maintain common areas. There is no discussion of premises liability or any obligation of a lessor to keep common areas safe for tenants. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the stated proposition about Massachusetts law on lessors’ duties to tenants.
*Lipsitz v. Smith*, 236 Mass. 72, 74 (19.relevant_excerpt: The will is distinguishable from that construed in Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co. v. Blanchard, 196 Mass. 35. Here it does not appear, as in that case, that the use of the words “heirs at law” excludes the issue of other children who must have died before its construction could be a necessity. If the son Ezra or the daughter Mary had died leaving issue, such issue would have taken a part of the principal of the trust property.

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165\.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes on lessors a duty to maintain common areas in a condition that does not endanger tenants’ safety.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165\.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that, under Massachusetts law, landlords owe a duty of reasonable care to maintain common passageways and areas they control in a safe condition for tenants and their guests. In discussing prior precedents (Lindsey and King), the court states that landlords have a general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways, and that the status of the entrant (tenant vs. visitor) does not change that duty. Although Young extends liability to demised premises, it reaffirms the existing duty as to common areas.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165\.relevant_excerpt: In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that “the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.” Id. at 82. In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant’s inaction in repairing the entry lock after repeated notice constitutes “direct or indirect interference” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with rent abatement for breach of the implied warranty of habitability due to lack of heat and hot water; it does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it discuss “direct or indirect interference” with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The case concerns strict liability for uninhabitable conditions and the timing of rent abatement after notice, not landlord inaction on entry locks or any § 14 claim. Therefore, it does not support the specific statutory-interference proposition stated.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition and (2) whether the tenant’s obligation to pay full rent persists until the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair the defect. We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The resulting repeated intrusions, theft, and lack of security are precisely the type of interferences deemed actionable in similar cases.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landlord’s failure to provide heat as a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not discuss repeated intrusions, theft, or lack of security, nor does it characterize those types of interferences as actionable. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that such security-related interferences are the type deemed actionable in similar cases.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Winthrop Realty Trust v. Schrank*, 15 M.raw_text: *Winthrop Realty Trust v. Schrank*, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1009 (1983)
*Winthrop Realty Trust v. Schrank*, 15 M.proposition: The resulting repeated intrusions, theft, and lack of security are precisely the type of interferences deemed actionable in similar cases.
*Winthrop Realty Trust v. Schrank*, 15 M.case_name: Allen v. Board of Selectmen of Weymouth
*Winthrop Realty Trust v. Schrank*, 15 M.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a police officer injured while driving home from court was acting “in the performance of his duties” for purposes of compensation under a Massachusetts statute. It does not involve landlord‑tenant issues, premises security, intrusions, theft, or any discussion of actionable interference based on lack of security. Using this opinion to support a proposition about repeated intrusions, theft, and security-related interference is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
*Winthrop Realty Trust v. Schrank*, 15 M.relevant_excerpt: “Whether Sergeant Allen’s accident occurred ‘in the performance of his duties,’ under the principles of the Wormstead case (at 664) is to be determined on the basis of his ‘employment in all of its aspects,’ including the ‘nature, conditions, obligations or incidents of the employment.’ … Here, Sergeant Allen was dispatched on a special mission by his employer. The activity, in the course of which the accident occurred, was a part of Sergeant Allen’s employment which accrued to his employer’s benefit.”

*Hemingway v. Taylor*, 203 Mass. 68, 71.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was knowing, willful, and in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s rights under the law.
*Hemingway v. Taylor*, 203 Mass. 68, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion is a land-title and statutory-construction case about the meaning of an early colonial order concerning ownership of tidal flats and the procedure for fact-finding in the Land Court. It does not discuss any party’s mental state, nor does it address knowing, willful, or reckless disregard of another’s rights. Nothing in the holding or reasoning concerns misconduct by a defendant toward a plaintiff, so it cannot serve as authority for the asserted proposition about willful or reckless conduct.
*Hemingway v. Taylor*, 203 Mass. 68, 71.relevant_excerpt: Most of the opinion deals with historical grants and the meaning of “ordinary lowe water marke”: “Upon the facts found, the judge made no error of law in holding that ‘the ordinary lowe water marke’ meant in 1640 the same as the line of ‘mean low water,’ as these words are now used…” There is no discussion of any defendant’s knowing, willful, or reckless disregard of another’s rights.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: COUNT I  Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment  (M.G.L. c. 186, § 14) — Plaintiff asserts a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 (listed in the Count I heading and Authorities Cited).

M.G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Listed in the Authorities Cited section of the complaint; no separate supporting sentence appears in the body of the complaint.
